texts.definition: Groups of game elements that together provide more benefits than they do individually.
markups: <style="Definition">Groups of game elements that together provide more benefits than they do individually.</style>

To encourage players to collect certain combinations of game elements, games can have rules that define some combinations as <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> that either let players win games when they have collected them, determine the winner based on enumerated list of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> when gameplay ends, or give bonuses when all used together.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mahjong">Mahjong</link></style> is played until a winning hand is achieved by a player, and this hand consists of a combination of the various categories of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> possible (''Pongs'', ''Kongs'', ''Chows'' and ''Eyes''). The score received for the winning hand depends on the combination of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> and since one receives extra points for certain combinations this can be viewed as a type of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> also. The much simpler <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style> <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go%20Fish">Go Fish</link></style> uses <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> similarly to end game instances.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and its derivatives (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Guts">Guts</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Texas%20Hold'em">Texas Hold'em</link></style>) make use of different types of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> which have an internal ranking against each other and which is used to determine winners when necessary. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style> is another <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Card%20Games">Card Game</link></style> that uses <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> differently; any series of cards (including only two cards) lets players only count the lowest card when scoring (the goal is to received as few points as possible).

<style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> are typically found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diablo%20series">Diablo series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>. Here they exist as groups of game items, typically armor or pairs of weapons, that when all equipped provide

<style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> exist in two main ways in games: either as ways of defining end conditions or defining scores or ranking when the end conditions has been met,  or as game elements that can provide <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> when used together.

The first use of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> is typically done through defining groups of <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style> that have some common characteristic to be <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mahjong">Mahjong</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go%20Fish">Go Fish</link></style> uses this to end the game when a player has a <style="Link"><link="hands">Hand</link></style> consisting only of sets (the hands may consists of <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, and may partial or wholly be public to the other players). When <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> rounds ends with a somebody having matched the last bet; here the various <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> possible (e.g. one pairs, two pairs, three of a kind, straight, flush, etc.) determine the winner. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/No%20Thanks!">No Thanks!</link></style> ends when all <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> have been taken some the players and here <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> lets players avoid getting points for all <style="Link"><link="cards">Cards</link></style> they have that form consecutive series except for the lowest one in the series. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Yahtzee">Yahtzee</link></style> shows that use of several <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> can be the basis for collecting <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> as well. Games that make use of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> for rankings or scoring typically also make use of <style="Link"><link="tiebreakers">Tiebreakers</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> that provide <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> typically consists of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, and can be seen as <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> of the actions of having picked them up or equipped them. What constitutes these <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> can be any type of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that can be used, e.g. <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>, but the perhaps most common use is different pieces of <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> or clothing. Games designed to provide these types of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> may wish to consider the randomness with which different parts of the <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> are made available through for example <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>.

Regardless of if the <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> are used for scoring or providing bonus effects, game designers have the option of making the relations between different types of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> follow <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style>.

It is difficult for <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> to be perceived as such if they do not diegetically match, that is <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> need to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> with each other even if other parts of the game break this.

<style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> are a way of modulating <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> by making certain combinations of these have additional effects to those they have individually. Quite naturally, this creates <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style> goals of several <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals, and as players near completion of these <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/sets">sets</link></style> can give rise to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>.

As mentioned above, using <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> of several different <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> together to gain additional bonuses are examples of <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style>. These types of <style="CurrentLink">Sets</style> are also typically <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>.
